arrange=
ment, and can be seen at
http://maven.apache.org/guides/introduction/introd=
uction-to-the-standard-directory-layout.html

This structure is used by a l=
ot of non-maven projects too, simply
because following a well known convent=
ion is better than making your
own.

An interesting side-effect of the mave=
n structure is that the unit test
resides in the same package as the class =
being tested. This permits the
use of package-level protection for exposing=
 "non-public" information
to the test. I know this is generally frowned upo=
n, but sometimes nice
anyway. Personally I find the semantics of using "pro=
tected" so much
more convoluted (that keyword communicates so many other th=
ings), so I
find package level protection as nice alternative without all t=
he
feelings that come with "protected".
